line: 'Once upon a midnight dreary
'Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore—'
'    While I nodded
'As of some one gently rapping
'"’Tis some visitor
column3: I muttered, tapping at my chamber door—'

line: '            Only this and nothing more."'
'    Ah
column3: distinctly I remember it was in the bleak December;'

line: 'And each separate dying ember wrought its ghost upon the floor.'
'    Eagerly I wished the morrow;—vainly I had sought to borrow'
'    From my books surcease of sorrow—sorrow for the lost Lenore—'
'For the rare and radiant maiden whom the angels name Lenore—'
'            Nameless here for evermore.'
'    And the silken
column4: uncertain rustling of each purple curtain'

line: 'Thrilled me—filled me with fantastic terrors never felt before;'
'    So that now
column3: to still the beating of my heart

line: '    "’Tis some visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door—'
'Some late visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door;—'
'            This it is and nothing more."'
'    Presently my soul grew stronger; hesitating then no longer
'"Sir
'    But the fact is I was napping
column3: and so gently you came rapping

line: '    And so faintly you came tapping
'That I scarce was sure I heard you"—here I opened wide the door;—'
'            Darkness there and nothing more.'
'    Deep into that darkness peering
'Doubting
column3: dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before;'

line: '    But the silence was unbroken
column3: and the stillness gave no token

line: '    And the only word there spoken was the whispered word
'This I whispered
column3: and an echo murmured back the word

line: '            Merely this and nothing more.'
'    Back into the chamber turning
column3: all my soul within me burning

line: 'Soon again I heard a tapping somewhat louder than before.'
'    "Surely
column3: said I, surely that is something at my window lattice;'

line: '      Let me see
'Let my heart be still a moment and this mystery explore;—'
'            ’Tis the wind and nothing more!"'
'    Open here I flung the shutter
column4: with many a flirt and flutter

line: 'In there stepped a stately Raven of the saintly days of yore;'
'    Not the least obeisance made he; not a minute stopped or stayed he;'
'    But
column3: with mien of lord or lady

line: 'Perched upon a bust of Pallas just above my chamber door—'
'            Perched
'Then this ebony bird beguiling my sad fancy into smiling
'By the grave and stern decorum of the countenance it wore
'"Though thy crest be shorn and shaven
column4: I said, art sure no craven

line: 'Ghastly grim and ancient Raven wandering from the Nightly shore—'
'Tell me what thy lordly name is on the Night’s Plutonian shore!"'
'            Quoth the Raven "Nevermore."'
'    Much I marvelled this ungainly fowl to hear discourse so plainly
'Though its answer little meaning—little relevancy bore;'
'    For we cannot help agreeing that no living human being'
'    Ever yet was blessed with seeing bird above his chamber door—'
'Bird or beast upon the sculptured bust above his chamber door
'            With such name as "Nevermore."'
'    But the Raven
column3: sitting lonely on the placid bust

line: 'That one word
column3: as if his soul in that one word he did outpour.'

line: '    Nothing farther then he uttered—not a feather then he fluttered—'
'    Till I scarcely more than muttered "Other friends have flown before—'
'On the morrow he will leave me
column3: as my Hopes have flown before."'

line: '            Then the bird said "Nevermore."'
'    Startled at the stillness broken by reply so aptly spoken
'"Doubtless
column3: said I, what it utters is its only stock and store'

line: '    Caught from some unhappy master whom unmerciful Disaster'
'    Followed fast and followed faster till his songs one burden bore—'
'Till the dirges of his Hope that melancholy burden bore'
'            Of ‘Never—nevermore’."'
'    But the Raven still beguiling all my fancy into smiling
'Straight I wheeled a cushioned seat in front of bird
'    Then
'    Fancy unto fancy
column3: thinking what this ominous bird of yore—'

line: 'What this grim
'            Meant in croaking "Nevermore."'
'    This I sat engaged in guessing
'To the fowl whose fiery eyes now burned into my bosom’s core;'
'    This and more I sat divining
column3: with my head at ease reclining'

line: '    On the cushion’s velvet lining that the lamp-light gloated o’er
'But whose velvet-violet lining with the lamp-light gloating o’er
'            She shall press
'    Then
'Swung by Seraphim whose foot-falls tinkled on the tufted floor.'
'    "Wretch
column3: I cried, thy God hath lent thee—by these angels he hath sent thee'

line: '    Respite—respite and nepenthe from thy memories of Lenore;'
'Quaff
column3: oh quaff this kind nepenthe and forget this lost Lenore!"'

line: '            Quoth the Raven "Nevermore."'
'    "Prophet!" said I
'Whether Tempter sent
column3: or whether tempest tossed thee here ashore

line: '    Desolate yet all undaunted
'    On this home by Horror haunted—tell me truly
'Is there—is there balm in Gilead?—tell me—tell me
'            Quoth the Raven "Nevermore."'
'    "Prophet!" said I
'By that Heaven that bends above us—by that God we both adore—'
'    Tell this soul with sorrow laden if
'    It shall clasp a sainted maiden whom the angels name Lenore—'
'Clasp a rare and radiant maiden whom the angels name Lenore."'
'            Quoth the Raven "Nevermore."'
'    "Be that word our sign of parting
'"Get thee back into the tempest and the Night’s Plutonian shore!'
'    Leave no black plume as a token of that lie thy soul hath spoken!'
'    Leave my loneliness unbroken!—quit the bust above my door!'
'Take thy beak from out my heart
column3: and take thy form from off my door!"'

line: '            Quoth the Raven "Nevermore."'
'    And the Raven
'On the pallid bust of Pallas just above my chamber door;'
'    And his eyes have all the seeming of a demon’s that is dreaming
'    And the lamp-light o’er him streaming throws his shadow on the floor;'
'And my soul from out that shadow that lies floating on the floor'
'            Shall be lifted—nevermore!'
